stories.story: You know, it’s funny the things that stick with you. It wasn’t a big fare, just a quiet ride before dawn. This passenger gets in, real quiet, carrying a slim violin case. We’re driving through the city just as it’s waking up, and the smell of bread from a bakery somewhere drifts in. He asked me if the city ever really sleeps. We just shared that quiet moment, you know? When he got out, he paid the exact fare and said, ‘Thanks, Anthony.’ It wasn’t the loud, crazy fares that made the job. It was the quiet ones, the human ones. That ride, that was a good one. It reminded me what the job was really about.

I remember this one ride, uh, way before sunrise. This guy had a violin case, a skinny one. The city was still dark, but you could smell the bakeries starting up. Warm bread. He was a quiet fella. He asked me something… uh, about the city being asleep. It was just a simple, peaceful drive. I think, yeah, I think he used my name when he left. It’s not the big, noisy trips you remember, you know? It’s the small ones. That one felt… real. Just a quiet moment in the cab.

There was this one time… real early. Still dark. A passenger, he had a... a violin, I think. In a case. We were driving, and the streets were empty. It smelled like, uh, baking bread. Nice. He said something to me. I don’t remember exactly what. Something about the city at night. It was… calm. Not like the usual chaos. He paid, and I think he said my name. Or maybe I’m mixed up. Anyway, it was one of those rides that just… it sticks with you. A good, quiet one. Yeah.

I had this fare, um, a long time ago. It was dark out. A man with a… a music case. A violin? Yeah. We drove. It was quiet. I remember the smell of bread. He asked… he asked a question. I can’t… I don’t recall the words. But it was a good question. It made me think. He was a nice man. Paid his fare. I think he knew my name. It’s funny, the things you… you hold onto. Just a simple ride, but, uh, it meant something. It was… yeah.

A man, he was in my cab. It was… night? Or morning? Real quiet. He had a… a box. A long one. For music. We were just… driving. And the bread smell. I remember that. He said… he said my name. Anthony. Yeah. He said, ‘Anthony.’ It was… nice. I, I think he asked something but I… I don’t know. It was a good ride. Quiet. Not like the others. Not loud. Just… quiet.

My cab… driving. There was a man. He was… quiet. So quiet. Had a… a thing. A case. Long. We, we drove. And the smell… bread. It was warm. He… um… he said my name. My name. He knew it. That was… that was good. I remember that. Just… quiet. In the car. Yeah. Quiet.
